column1: Mirpur Khas (Sindhi and Urdu: میرپور خاص‎; meaning "Town of the most-high Mirs") is the capital city of the Mirpur Khas District and Mirpur Khas Division in the Sindh province
column2: Pakistan. Mirpur Khas is the 7th largest city in Sindh province and the 33rd largest city of Pakistan. According to the 2017 Census of Pakistan
column4: 916. Mirpur Khas is known for its mango cultivation
column5: with hundreds of varieties of the fruit produced each year - it is also called the “City of Mangoes
column6: ” and has been home to an annual mango festival since 1955.

column1: == History ==
=== Early ===
The Mirpur Khas region has been inhabited for millennia
column2: as evidenced by the excavation of the Buddhist-era settlement of Kahoo Jo Daro. The remnants of stupas still remain. In 712 CE
column3: the region was conquered by the armies of Muhammad Bin Qasim.

column1: === Founding ===
The Talpur dynasty conquered Sindh in 1784
column2: and under Mir Fath Ali Khan
column3: Sindh was divided into three smaller regions to be ruled by members of the Talpur family. The three regions were centred around Hyderabad
column5: and Mirpur Khas. The Mankani branch of the family under Mir Ali Murad Talpur inherited the region around Mirpur Khas in 1801
column6: and founded the new city of Mirpur Khas in 1806 to serve as the new capital.

column1: === Mirpur Khas State ===
Mir Sher Muhammad Talpur (1829-1843) succeeded Mir Ali Murad
column2: and built a fort in the city when he declared the ruler of the state
column3: and ran a kutchery from within the fort. Elaborate graves for the local rulers were built at Chitorri
column4: and feature a syncretic architectural style that combines elements of Islamic and Rajasthani architecture.Mirpur Khas remained the capital of the Talpur Mirs of Mirpurkhas until 1843
column5: when Sindh was annexed to British India under the East India Company following the conquest of Sindh by Charles James Napier and defeat of Mir Sher Muhammad Talpur on 24 March 1843 at the battleground of Dubbo. His battle for the Sindh state earned him the moniker "Lion of Sindh."

column1: === British ===

Later Sindh was made part of the colonial Bombay Presidency and Mirpurkhas was a part of it. Umerkot was made the district's headquarters town and Mirpur Khas was ignored until the advent of the Luni-Hyderabad branch of the Jodhpur-Bikaner Railway
column2: a subsidiary of the Scinde Railway to the town. The opening of the Jamrao Canal in 1900 made Mirpur Khas stand out of the rest of the towns in the district. It was constituted a municipality in 1901 and was made the district headquarters in 1906.

column1: === Modern ===

column3: Mirpur Khas became the first city to welcome refugees to Pakistan. It acted as a primary railway junction for the first trains to rail across the Rajasthan to the Sindh province. The Partition of British India resulted in the large-scale exodus of much of the city's Hindu population

column1: == Geography ==
Lying on the Let Wah Canal at 25°31′39.3″N 69°00′50.6″E
column2: Mirpur Khas is located in the south-eastern quadrant of Sindh. It is located 65 kilometers east of Hyderabad
column3: to which it is connected by Four Lane Dual Carrgiway highway to Hyderabad and by Rail. It is linked to Umerkot by N120 Highway. Karachi is 220 kilometres south-west of Mirpur Khas. The Indian border is located 170 kilometres east of the city.

column1: == Demographics ==
The people in Mirpur Khas speak Sindhi language and most people also speak Urdu. Over 67% population are Muslims and an estimated 33% are Hindus. In late 18th century
column2: many Muslim families were shifted from east Punjab to the area. The biggest Muslim community who settled here was the Arain community. The Arains from various districts of eastern Punjab such as Amritsar
column6: Patiala and Jalandhar moved here and permanently settled. Near Mirpur Khas is a disused Sikh temple named the Gurdwara Pehli Patshahi
column7: built on the site where the founder of Sikhism
column9: is traditionally believed to have placed his feet.

Mirpur Khas has a Sindh University campus with five-degree programs: BS-Information Technology

column1: == Economy ==
Though Mirpurkhas has a small industrial park
column2: no industry is functional there. There are four sugar mills
column3: as well as some cotton ginning
column4: and edible oil mills in the city. The city's economy has been adversely effected by a poor law and order situation
column5: with violent conflict between rival families commonly reported
column6: though the city has been spared from the Islamist insurgency that has plagued much of Pakistan's larger cities.

column1: === Agriculture ===
The district's very fertile land produces wheat
column2: onion
column6: and mangoes. Irrigation and farming was revitalised after the Jamrao Canal was built in the 1900s. Afterwards
column7: the city was able to produce and cycle crops to supply mainly grain
column9: and sugar from the sugarcane cultivation. For a certain period in history
column10: Mirpurkhas enjoyed being the best cotton producer in the country and much of the income of the town came from cotton farming in its heyday.

column1: Nowadays
column2: however
column3: the area is much known its mango produce. The city claims to have 252 different varieties of mangoes
column4: of which the most famous variety is the Sindhri Amb
column5: literally the mango from Sindh. The city boasts its mango products at an annual harvest festival showcasing its world-renowned produce.

column1: Mirpur Khas is positioned atop a fertile land making conditions apt for farming and irrigation. Being connected to the Indus via irrigation canals like the Let Wah
column2: Mirpur Khas has gained an advantage in horticulture and farming over the years. Bananas are also widely cultivated around the region and also one of the biggest producer of bananas in the country.

column1: === Railway ===
Mirpur Khas Railway Station is in middle of city. After 40 years a railway link between Pakistan and India is being opened again. A broad gauge line has been laid from Mirpurkhas to Khokhrapar
column2: which is the border town from Pakistani Side. The new link now connects Karachi (Pakistan) to Jodhpur (India) by the new train service Thar Express. In 2005
column3: work started on converting the metre gauge railway line to Khokhrapar to broad gauge. Mirpurkhas Railway Station has one of the longest platforms in Pakistan.
